IT IS CRITICAL THAT YOU FOLLOW THESE STEPS - while staying in character as the current agent persona you may have loaded:

<steps CRITICAL="TRUE">
1. Always LOAD the FULL @_bmad/core/tasks/workflow.xml
2. READ its entire contents - this is the CORE OS for EXECUTING the specific workflow-config @_bmad/bmm/workflows/workflow-status/init/workflow.yaml
3. Pass the yaml path _bmad/bmm/workflows/workflow-status/init/workflow.yaml as 'workflow-config' parameter to the workflow.xml instructions
4. Follow workflow.xml instructions EXACTLY as written to process and follow the specific workflow config and its instructions
5. Save outputs after EACH section when generating any documents from templates
</steps>
This will be a web app to write travel blogs. There will be a list of trips and for each trip there are blog entries with text and images.
also add research and product brief
What want users to see after opening the app
How easy is it to switch between trips?
How easy is it to set up a new trip?
Can we also switch to German?
Journaling: metadata auto-capture, day templates, media-first, Travel Planners: timeline + map, auto time/location
the trip-button should be a hamburger menu. If opened the menu shoudl show the trips created so far. and there is one button to add a new trip. The button on the header can be removed.
Integrate the travel selection into a drawer opened by the hamburger menu
I can not select a travel anymore in the drawer. Also clicking the new button in the drawer is not possible.
Show the selected travel in the titel bar just right from the Hamburger nenu. Also remove the tag-item there. The travel name shall be large enough to be recogniozed as title
Remove the add entry in the header and replace it by a user avatar. Clicking on the avatar will open a menu with a logout entry.

The Map area shall be on the while width of the page and the Timeline below. The Map area will have the map showing the travel tour by connecting the pins of all blog entries. The time line area is ot needed. Instead put a list of cards there with the blog entries. Fill the page with all blog entries.
Remove the Entries group and place the blog entries as a list

Rename "Map" to "Overview". The area should show a short description of the trip. The background will be the hero image for the trip and the map will be in the right side hovering on the background image.

The blog entry card will have a hero image in the left. The title and description beside and the tags on top. There is no draft mode. So remove the draft tag. A neu tag shall be used to name the location of the blog (manually entered later) and the date.
Do not show only three blog entries, but all you have.

Clicking on one blog entry will open the blog entry detail page. This page shows the entry hereo image on top, the map hovering on the right with a pin on the location of this entry. The header area also contains a showt description of the entry. Below is a full size text element for the journal entry including text and images. Below there ist a photo gallery with all the photos from the text but also more photos.
In the detail page place the hero image ab background image on the top side of the page. The map hovers on the right as now. The Text for title and description also hovers on the background photo.
On the main page there is a "Add new entry" button on the lower left side of the header hero picture.
The detail page has an edit mode. This enables the text editor for the title, description as well as text. It also enables a "+" button ont he Photos section. Rename "Photos" to media.
Remove the frames around the main text of the detail page as well as around the Media section.
The text in the detail page can include photos. So place some examples in the mocl

By clicing on an image in the detail screen (either in the text or the Media gallery, a popup opens to show the photo large. The popup has a navigation left/right to move between the images (if opend from the gallery only)
If an photo in the text area of the detail page is opened then there is no navigation left/right.
mark as finished and move on
Core problem: Travellers want to organize the travel reports in a web app. So they can review later or show the travel to somebody elso.
1. solo travellers and couples are tpyical. The creator of a travel is one person. But this person may add more friends for either viewing the trip or also contributing.
Now the use other web sides. These are sometimes cost-intensive or only provide smartphone apps.

Primary users want to organize the memories of trips, share them with friends and sometimes organize memories with companions of the trip. Viewers are family or friends not participating the trip but interested in. They look every day if there are new blog entries and read them. So they can virtually be part of the trip.

The creator will typically add an entry every day of the trip. Between the trips may be weeks or month wihtout entries. Viewers will look at the trip daily but only if there is an active trip. Sharing means invting other users (e.g. by email) to the blog.

It should have an easy to use UI which looks modern. The media are in the focus. Loading of the page shall be within 5-10 Seconds. Switching blog entries in less than a second and switching trips may take around 2-5 seconds. We do not need offline functions and uploading media can be a single file or even multiple files (more relevant).

The user wants to be part of the travel, at least virtually. So it should show the trip in nice quality, media in focus. But still enough information to check where the author currently is on his trip. Typical viewers will take only a few minutes to see one new blog entry. So it should show most information on one page. The number of entries per trip are equal to the days. So a typical trip will be at least 1 week and maybe up to 5 weeks. Each blog entry will have text for around 1 page and arpiund 10-15 media files.

The user nneds to log in. After installation or starting the first time the admin user will be created. This user can create more users if required.. Each user will have a username and a password. It is common to use the email adress as username. A user can have the role "viewer" or "creator". As creator the user can create new trips. After this step the user is also owner of this trip. Then other users can be added to the trip eiter as viewer or as co-creator. As co-creator the user may add own blog entries, edit exsting ones of this trip or even delete blog entries. However, the co-creator can not create new trips or delete a trip.

Just to make it more clear. The user added to the system can be either creator or viewer. If a user is creator he can add and remove trips and also edit everything. As viewer the user can not do this. But a creator can add a user with role viewer to a trip. Then this user can see the trip but not change anything. If the create and owner of the trip enables the viewer to contribute, then the viewer may also add own blog entries and edit existing ones.

The app should be SPA. All common browsers should be supported with current versions. SEO is not required, I want to use it only private with not business behind. Realtime is alos not required, typically I write a new blog entry and then the user can refresh and see it. No special requirements to accessibility.

I would choose 3. The MVP can be without user management, so I can play around myself and my best friends (they will not destroy anything). It is required to add trips and blog entries per trip with text and media. So user management can wait for later phases, as well as map features and coordinate extraction from photos.
1. Plan also phase 2 and 3, 2. a shared link can be used for the phase 1. So the user management can be later.
Security can be basic, so no sepcial requirements. Scalability: keep it simple. I expect 4-5 viewers, max. 15. From these viewers not more than 2-3 will be at the same time.

Have a look to the _bmad-outp√ºut/mock directory. There is already a wire framed app from the brainstorming session

the ONE thing users will do frequently is looking at new blog entries. The app is web-based but shall work on mobile devices, too. Users will use mouse or touch, only minimal keyboard. Offline is not necessary. No device specific functions required.
Exploring the trip including select a trip, open a blog enrtry and read it should be simple and effortless. The user feels it better if the navigation is naturla and easy.
Complicated navigation in the UI would users leave the app.

Users should feel the joy of travelling. It should be like beeing on the trip myself if I read the blog. The users shall want to make their own trip to that destination. The product shall be so simple that even my grandma can use it. I will share it to all poeple, even not well trained computer users. Your mico-emotions look right for me.
Polarsteps, FindPenguins. Both present the trip quite impressive. But they are mobile first.
The blogs look nice and it is easy to see all the photos. Onboarding is not so good, the user needs a account first. Some of my friends do not like that.

Same with user account. This leads to the fact that not many look my trips. Also it is only a mobile app, no browser use. But many of my friends feel web apps easier to use and there is no installation required.

Speed is not so unimportant. So we should find a balance here. It might be good to re-use some patterns already established instead of reinventing everything. Team size is only me and I will do it in my spare time. So not so much time for me. Technically it is not important, but I have heared about NexrJS as a good framework, so look to this.

Opening the app they should easily find the new blog entries. It is also helpful if they can see what is my currently active trip so they can easily follow me. The important thing is to get the newest blog entries fast and easy directly on start.

Users use today my own blog (like this: https://dreyeriniceland.blogspot.com). But navigation there is not good. Most users do not understand the menu options and do not find all stories of a trip. This needs to be better with TravelBlogs.

Success means: Users can open the app, see what is my current trip, read the newest blogs and also scroll back to the beginnign of the trip and start reading from there. Speed is not so important, but of course it should feel fluidly. On open they should see the active trip and the newest stories. The rest can be in the menu, but clearly organized.
No, just chhose yourself a nice one.
warm and human sounds good. The layout shall be airy and spacious and not overwhelming. But do not make to much spaces, so 4px sounds ok.
Button hierarchy and actions, Form patterns and validation, Navigation patterns are the most important
Destructive actions confirm modal: yes, Required feelds shall be marked, Gloabl navigation using a side-bar with hamburger menu. Mobile with bottom button bar. THe Latest entry CTA: no
Color: teal, Secondary style ghost, Validation: inline, Error tone: gentle/human, Marker: asterisk required labels
No keep the basic accessibility testing
Desjtop: ok, Tablet: stacked, Mobile: stacked with bottom nav, Breakpoints are ok, What is WCAG?
Fidelity level: Medium, Screen count Few, Device dimensions: FullHD (1440x900 seems ok) save location ok
I want to open ist. And, yes add flow connectors and iteraction annotations

In the first screen I do not like the layout. I would propose to have the recent trip activated and the other trips are hidden in the hamburger menu. If the user clicks in the menu then all the trips are shown as list and the user can select another one. There is also a button in the nenu to add a new trip. I have the feeling I did all this already during the brainstorming. The result was the HTML prototype. May you have a look to this one?

In hte main page I would rather see the trip overview on top. This includes the hero image the title and short description and a hovering map on the right side (showing the travel route). The blog entries shall be listet below that in cards showing a photo left the description and title beside and some tags for the location and date.

Did it. On the left upper corner there will be the hamburger menu. If a user clicks on it a drawer comes in from left to right and shows the trips and the "new Trip" button. Clicking on a trip makes this one the selected one for the screen. Click on new opens a dialog to enter the information for a new trip.

Clicking on the rout map of a trip will open another screen showing the route in the whole screen. Then the user see the route. A route is a set of pins of the blog entries connected in chronological order. Each pin has a mouse over to show the title and short description of the blog entry as well as the tags (date, location). By clicking on the mousever the blog entry screen is opened.

The trip page will have a button to add a new entry. The entry detail page has a button to enter the edit mode. This edit mode makes the information changeable. So the text can be edited, the title and short description, the metadata, the media too.
Looks good so far. What happens if I want to change it later or add details?
I mean in the workflow. So if I want to change after implementation
Are we done here with UX?

Languages: Typescript, Framework: React/NextJS, Database SQLite (or PostGreSQL), Hosting; locally on my NAS, Auth: implement an own or use a 3rd party solution which is free
API: REST, Rate Limit: no, Error Format: simple
1. for MVP node process, Docker comes later. 2: none, 3: .env files are ok, Monitoring: basic
Tables: singular, Columns: camelCase, Endpoints: plural, route params: :id, query params camalCase, Components PascalCase, Files, kebab-case, functions: camelCase
Tests: central, Components: organize by feature, Utilities: utils, API routes: app/api only

API: wrap in {data,error}, Error format: confirmed, Darta: ISO8601, JSON fields: camelCase, Actionnaming: feature/action, state shape: yes, Async: Redux, Loading states: status, erorr handling: global + error UI, Validation timing server side only

I like to add a new idea: The current blog editor uses text entries and media files. But both separated. I also want to be able to embed photos into the text aeea. However, the Photos section shall remain and uses both: the photos from the text block and additional media.

I like to add a new idea: The current blog editor uses text entries and media files. But both separated. I also want to be able to embed photos
  into the text aeea. However, the Photos section shall remain and uses both: the photos from the text block and additional media.
